Articles.Content:
Heard from a friend, Daz3D is making their Daz Studio 4, Bryce Pro 7, and Hexagon 2.5 available for free for a limited time. They\'ll ask you for an e-mail address and a newsletter signup, so you\'ll need an e-mail address you don\'t mind giving them, but it beats paying $800+ for the software.

More info on their site

(Note: I am not affiliated with Daz3D in any way, shape, or form. I just know there are probably people here who would be interested in this. Cheers!)

Cool, products that cost money but have limited free offers are always welcome!

Thanks for saving me a few couple hundred bucks bro.

Nice. I was going to say that Daz and Bryce don\'t use polygons (loooong story) so are useless for modelling.

However! They seem to have fixed that by making a third piece of software called Hexagon. But I\'ve never seen or used it before so don\'t know if it\'s compatible with KSP...

Oh, the loooong story is, Bryce and Daz tend to use a different type of modelling system than most other software. They mainly use procedural and fractal generation. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractal_landscape

So the files don\'t save a model or space ship for example, just the commands and maths to generate one from the procedural system.

PS, I\'ve actually got a full copy of Bryce 2 or 3 lying around. They were actually a great company (Taken over by Corel, now Daz) who gave away old copies for free when the new versions came out as advertising. Truespace 6/7 is also another one released for free when they eventually closed down.

[edit]

Hexigon seems to have the tools needed to make parts, but not the exporter. But with the downloads you can do Hexagon model exported to Daz 4 then export to Collada for KSP. I\'ll see if I can get it working in the week then we can add this software to the list of usable tools.

GET THIS WHILE YOU CAN! I suggest registering and 'purchasing' (no payment details taken!) so you can download at a later date.

Thanks for the info, Ben! I actually haven\'t had a chance to play with it yet.

A note on the 'download at a later date' - The 'Download Window' I saw on the screen ended Feb 8th. So move quick if you want it!

From their announcement thread:

DAZ Studio 4 Pro, Bryce 7 Pro and Hexagon 2.5 are available via download only on DAZ3D.com between now and February 29, 2012 for free.

The real question is: I 'bought' all three for 0 dollars and the downloads + code show up in my account. Since I have the codes, will I be able to download them in perpetuity, or do I have to install and register them before the end of the sale? I can\'t seem to find the answer.

I would -assume- that they remain on your account, but, I would like an answer too.

Seems like a great offer. I registered and I am awaiting my activation email. I\'ll update this as it develops!Misspelled email so I had to re-register. All good and downloading now. It says on my page that the downloads expire on the 11th so I suggest you get on it quick!

I just looked, and for me it says the 10th. Either timezone differences, or it depends on when you accept the offer.

Strange that. I\'d assume the product keys are valid forever though right? I guess I\'m use to being spoilt on Steam. It\'s got to be the worse download service ever if you only have a week to download. Puts me right off buying anything from them in the future.

[edit]

Under 'purchase history' you can request a 'download reset'. So presumably you could download at a later date, as your account will show you never downloaded the first time. Customer services would have a hard time arguing you are not allowed to download it at least once. But I\'ve not read the T&Cs.

Mine expire the 8th, and I registered the 1st day this was posted (the 3rd) so I guess you get 5 days.

I think I may pass on installing it anyway, as they have this CMS program that must run as a service in Windows and get access through the system firewall in order to \'share data with our suite of software locally\' - it claims to never connect to the Internet, but the service must be running for the software to function.

As they say; Nothing is ever free.

Ok, I\'ll check if it can be disabled. Sounds like a 'search and linking' tool. Like Googles search box in Sketchup. Or the bridging software (optional) in Photoshop/Indesign. So AFAIK the CMS thing is entirely optional, and you can disable it. It\'s not a spyware...

[edit]

Yep, it\'s only to allow you to use the folders and files in the DAZ program with ease. You can disable it. I suppose it\'s like .Zip integration that shows in right click. Or Thumbnail integration so you can see previews. But mainly it means when you click your 'files' icon or whatever in DAZ it know where all your pictures/objects/textures are without having to link them manually.

http://forum.daz3d.com/viewtopic.php?t=162343

Best option seems to be to click 'manual install' and unselect the CMS tool from the options list. This should avoid it all together. I think the call to the internet is just checking if you have a network HDD for it to find the tutorials/textures/objects etc on.

Here it is March 6th and this free software is still available as of right now. I\'m downloading as we speak.

DAZ has done this before, free full apps given out usually just a month or two before a new version comes out.
